This is also configurable at run time (see Task Watchdog Timer API Reference)
children.name: ESP_TASK_WDT_TIMEOUT_S
children.title: Task Watchdog timeout period (seconds)

children.help:
If this option is enabled, the Task Watchdog Timer will watch the CPU0
Idle Task. Having the Task Watchdog watch the Idle Task allows for detection
of CPU starvation as the Idle Task not being called is usually a symptom of
CPU starvation. Starvation of the Idle Task is detrimental as FreeRTOS household
tasks depend on the Idle Task getting some runtime every now and then.
children.name: ESP_TASK_WDT_CHECK_IDLE_TASK_CPU0
children.title: Watch CPU0 Idle Task

children.help:
If this option is enabled, the Task Wtachdog Timer will wach the CPU1
Idle Task.
children.name: ESP_TASK_WDT_CHECK_IDLE_TASK_CPU1
children.title: Watch CPU1 Idle Task

children.help:
The Task Watchdog Timer can be used to make sure individual tasks are still
running. Enabling this option will cause the Task Watchdog Timer to be
initialized automatically at startup. The Task Watchdog timer can be
initialized after startup as well (see Task Watchdog Timer API Reference)
children.name: ESP_TASK_WDT
children.title: Initialize Task Watchdog Timer on startup

children.help: Timeout period configuration for the XTAL32K watchdog timer based on RTC_CLK.
children.name: ESP_XT_WDT_TIMEOUT
children.title: XTAL32K watchdog timeout period

children.help:
Enable this to automatically switch to BACKUP32K_CLK as the source of RTC_SLOW_CLK when
the watchdog timer expires.
children.name: ESP_XT_WDT_BACKUP_CLK_ENABLE
children.title: Automatically switch to BACKUP32K_CLK when timer expires

children.help:
This watchdog timer can detect oscillation failure of the XTAL32K_CLK. When such a failure
is detected the hardware can be set up to automatically switch to BACKUP32K_CLK and generate
an interrupt.
children.name: ESP_XT_WDT
children.title: Initialize XTAL32K watchdog timer on startup

children.help:
If this option is disabled (default), the panic handler code is placed in flash not IRAM.
This means that if ESP-IDF crashes while flash cache is disabled, the panic handler will
automatically re-enable flash cache before running GDB Stub or Core Dump. This adds some minor
risk, if the flash cache status is also corrupted during the crash.

If this option is enabled, the panic handler code (including required UART functions) is placed
in IRAM. This may be necessary to debug some complex issues with crashes while flash cache is
disabled (for example, when writing to SPI flash) or when flash cache is corrupted when an exception
is triggered.
children.name: ESP_PANIC_HANDLER_IRAM
children.title: Place panic handler code in IRAM

children.help:
Debug stubs are used by OpenOCD to execute pre-compiled onboard code
which does some useful debugging stuff, e.g. GCOV data dump.
children.name: ESP_DEBUG_STUBS_ENABLE

children.help: Using level 5 interrupt for Interrupt Watchdog and other system checks.
children.name: ESP_SYSTEM_CHECK_INT_LEVEL_5
children.title: Level 5 interrupt

children.help: Using level 4 interrupt for Interrupt Watchdog and other system checks.
children.name: ESP_SYSTEM_CHECK_INT_LEVEL_4
children.title: Level 4 interrupt

children.help: Interrupt level to use for Interrupt Watchdog and other system checks.
children.name: ESP_SYSTEM_CHECK_INT_LEVEL
children.title: Interrupt level to use for Interrupt Watchdog and other system checks

children.help:
This version of FreeRTOS normally takes control of all cores of
the CPU. Select this if you only want to start it on the first core.
This is needed when e.g. another process needs complete control
over the second core.

# This invisible config value sets the value of tskNO_AFFINITY in task.h.
# Intended to be used as a constant from other Kconfig files.
# Value is (32-bit) INT_MAX.
children.name: FREERTOS_UNICORE
children.title: Run FreeRTOS only on first core

children.help: Select this to use timer 0
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_0
children.title: Timer 0 (int 6, level 1)

children.help: Select this to use timer 1
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_1
children.title: Timer 1 (int 15, level 3)

children.help: Select this to use systimer with the 1 interrupt priority.
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_SYSTIMER_LVL1
children.title: SYSTIMER 0 (level 1)

children.help: Select this to use systimer with the 3 interrupt priority.
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_SYSTIMER_LVL3
children.title: SYSTIMER 0 (level 3)

children.help:
FreeRTOS needs a timer with an associated interrupt to use as
the main tick source to increase counters, run timers and do
pre-emptive multitasking with. There are multiple timers available
to do this, with different interrupt priorities. Check
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER
children.title: Xtensa timer to use as the FreeRTOS tick source

children.help:
On most platforms there are instructions can speedup the ready task
searching. Enabling this option the FreeRTOS with this instructions
support will be built.
children.name: FREERTOS_OPTIMIZED_SCHEDULER
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS pĺatform optimized scheduler

children.help: Select the tick rate at which FreeRTOS does pre-emptive context switching.
children.name: FREERTOS_HZ
children.title: Tick rate (Hz)

children.help:
Some functions in FreeRTOS have not been thoroughly tested yet when moving to
the SMP implementation of FreeRTOS. When this option is enabled, these fuctions
will throw an assert().
children.name: FREERTOS_ASSERT_ON_UNTESTED_FUNCTION
children.title: Halt when an SMP-untested function is called

children.help: Do not check for stack overflows (configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW=0)
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW_NONE
children.title: No checking

children.help:
Check for stack overflows on each context switch by checking if
the stack pointer is in a valid range. Quick but does not detect
stack overflows that happened between context switches
(configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW=1)
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW_PTRVAL
children.title: Check by stack pointer value

children.help:
Places some magic bytes at the end of the stack area and on each
context switch, check if these bytes are still intact. More thorough
than just checking the pointer, but also slightly slower.
(configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW=2)
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW_CANARY
children.title: Check using canary bytes

children.help:
FreeRTOS can check for stack overflows in threads and trigger an user function
called vApplicationStackOverflowHook when this happens.
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW
children.title: Check for stack overflow

children.help:
FreeRTOS can check if a stack has overflown its bounds by checking either the value of
the stack pointer or by checking the integrity of canary bytes. (See FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW
for more information.) These checks only happen on a context switch, and the situation that caused
the stack overflow may already be long gone by then. This option will use the last debug memory
watchpoint to allow breaking into the debugger (or panic'ing) as soon as any
of the last 32 bytes on the stack of a task are overwritten. The side effect is that using gdb, you
effectively have one hardware watchpoint less because the last one is overwritten as soon as a task
switch happens.

Another consequence is that due to alignment requirements of the watchpoint, the usable stack size
decreases by up to 60 bytes. This is because the watchpoint region has to be aligned to its size and the
size for the stack watchpoint in IDF is 32 bytes.

This check only triggers if the stack overflow writes within 32 bytes near the end of the stack, rather
than overshooting further, so it is worth combining this approach with one of the other stack overflow
check methods.

When this watchpoint is hit, gdb will stop with a SIGTRAP message. When no JTAG OCD is attached, esp-idf
will panic on an unhandled debug exception.
children.name: FREERTOS_WATCHPOINT_END_OF_STACK
children.title: Set a debug watchpoint as a stack overflow check

children.help:
If this option is enabled, interrupt stack frame will be modified to
point to the code of the interrupted task as its return address.
This helps the debugger (or the panic handler) show a backtrace from
the interrupt to the task which was interrupted. This also works for
nested interrupts: higer level interrupt stack can be traced back to the
lower level interrupt.
This option adds 4 instructions to the interrupt dispatching code.
children.name: FREERTOS_INTERRUPT_BACKTRACE
children.title: Enable backtrace from interrupt to task context

children.help:
FreeRTOS has the ability to store per-thread pointers in the task
control block. This controls the number of pointers available.

This value must be at least 1. Index 0 is reserved for use by the pthreads API
thread-local-storage. Other indexes can be used for any desired purpose.
children.name: FREERTOS_THREAD_LOCAL_STORAGE_POINTERS
children.title: Number of thread local storage pointers

children.help:
If a FreeRTOS configASSERT() fails, FreeRTOS will abort() and
halt execution. The panic handler can be configured to handle
the outcome of an abort() in different ways.

If assertions are disabled for the entire project, they are also
disabled in FreeRTOS and this option is unavailable.
children.name: FREERTOS_ASSERT_FAIL_ABORT
children.title: abort() on failed assertions

children.help: If a FreeRTOS assertion fails, print it out and continue.
children.name: FREERTOS_ASSERT_FAIL_PRINT_CONTINUE
children.title: Print and continue failed assertions

children.help: FreeRTOS configASSERT() will not be compiled into the binary.
children.name: FREERTOS_ASSERT_DISABLE
children.title: Disable FreeRTOS assertions

children.help:
Failed FreeRTOS configASSERT() assertions can be configured to
behave in different ways.

By default these behave the same as the global project assert settings.
children.name: FREERTOS_ASSERT
children.title: FreeRTOS assertions

children.help:
The idle task has its own stack, sized in bytes. The default size is enough for most uses. Size can be
reduced to 768 bytes if no (or simple) FreeRTOS idle hooks are used and pthread local storage or FreeRTOS
local storage cleanup callbacks are not used.

The stack size may need to be increased above the default if the app installs idle or thread local storage
cleanup hooks that use a lot of stack memory.
children.name: FREERTOS_IDLE_TASK_STACKSIZE
children.title: Idle Task stack size

children.help:
The interrupt handlers have their own stack. The size of the stack can be defined here.
Each processor has its own stack, so the total size occupied will be twice this.
children.name: FREERTOS_ISR_STACKSIZE
children.title: ISR stack size

children.help:
FreeRTOS offers a number of hooks/callback functions that are called when a timer
tick happens, the idle thread runs etc. esp-idf replaces these by runtime registerable
hooks using the esp_register_freertos_xxx_hook system, but for legacy reasons the old
hooks can also still be enabled. Please enable this only if you have code that for some
reason can't be migrated to the esp_register_freertos_xxx_hook system.
children.name: FREERTOS_LEGACY_HOOKS
children.title: Use FreeRTOS legacy hooks

children.help:
Changes the maximum task name length. Each task allocated will
include this many bytes for a task name. Using a shorter value
saves a small amount of RAM, a longer value allows more complex
names.

For most uses, the default of 16 is OK.
children.name: FREERTOS_MAX_TASK_NAME_LEN
children.title: Maximum task name length

children.name: FREERTOS_ENABLE_STATIC_TASK_CLEAN_UP
children.title: Enable static task clean up hook

children.help:
The timer service task (primarily) makes use of existing FreeRTOS features, allowing timer
functionality to be added to an application with minimal impact on the size of the application's
executable binary.

Use this constant to define the priority that the timer task will run at.
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_TASK_PRIORITY
children.title: FreeRTOS timer task priority

children.help:
The timer service task (primarily) makes use of existing FreeRTOS features, allowing timer
functionality to be added to an application with minimal impact on the size of the application's
executable binary.

Use this constant to define the size (in bytes) of the stack allocated for the timer task.
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_TASK_STACK_DEPTH
children.title: FreeRTOS timer task stack size

children.help:
FreeRTOS provides a set of timer related API functions. Many of these functions use a standard
FreeRTOS queue to send commands to the timer service task. The queue used for this purpose is
called the 'timer command queue'. The 'timer command queue' is private to the FreeRTOS timer
implementation, and cannot be accessed directly.

For most uses the default value of 10 is OK.
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_QUEUE_LENGTH
children.title: FreeRTOS timer queue length

children.help:
FreeRTOS uses the queue registry as a means for kernel aware debuggers to locate queues, semaphores,
and mutexes. The registry allows for a textual name to be associated with a queue for easy identification
within a debugging GUI. A value of 0 will disable queue registry functionality, and a value larger than 0
will specify the number of queues/semaphores/mutexes that the registry can hold.
children.name: FREERTOS_QUEUE_REGISTRY_SIZE
children.title: FreeRTOS queue registry size

children.help:
If enabled, this will include an extra column when vTaskList is called
to display the CoreID the task is pinned to (0,1) or -1 if not pinned.
children.name: FREERTOS_VTASKLIST_INCLUDE_COREID
children.title: Enable display of xCoreID in vTaskList

children.help:
If enabled, configUSE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS will be defined as 1 in
FreeRTOS. This will allow the usage of stats formatting functions such
as vTaskList().
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS stats formatting functions

children.help:
If enabled, configUSE_TRACE_FACILITY will be defined as 1 in FreeRTOS.
This will allow the usage of trace facility functions such as
uxTaskGetSystemState().
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TRACE_FACILITY
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS trace facility

children.help:
ESP Timer will be used as the clock source for FreeRTOS run time stats.
The ESP Timer runs at a frequency of 1MHz regardless of Dynamic
Frequency Scaling. Therefore the ESP Timer will overflow in
approximately 4290 seconds.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_USING_ESP_TIMER
children.title: Use ESP TIMER for run time stats

children.help:
CPU Clock will be used as the clock source for the generation of run
time stats. The CPU Clock has a frequency dependent on
ESP32_DEFAULT_CPU_FREQ_MHZ and Dynamic Frequency Scaling (DFS).
Therefore the CPU Clock frequency can fluctuate between 80 to 240MHz.
Run time stats generated using the CPU Clock represents the number of
CPU cycles each task is allocated and DOES NOT reflect the amount of
time each task runs for (as CPU clock frequency can change). If the CPU
clock consistently runs at the maximum frequency of 240MHz, it will
overflow in approximately 17 seconds.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_USING_CPU_CLK
children.title: Use CPU Clock for run time stats

children.help:
Choose the clock source for FreeRTOS run time stats. Options are CPU0's
CPU Clock or the ESP Timer. Both clock sources are 32 bits. The CPU
Clock can run at a higher frequency hence provide a finer resolution
but will overflow much quicker. Note that run time stats are only valid
until the clock source overflows.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_CLK
children.title: Choose the clock source for run time stats

children.help:
If enabled, configGENERATE_RUN_TIME_STATS will be defined as 1 in
FreeRTOS. This will allow FreeRTOS to collect information regarding the
usage of processor time amongst FreeRTOS tasks. Run time stats are
generated using either the ESP Timer or the CPU Clock as the clock
source (Note that run time stats are only valid until the clock source
overflows). The function vTaskGetRunTimeStats() will also be available
if FREERTOS_USE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS and
FREERTOS_USE_TRACE_FACILITY are enabled. vTaskGetRunTimeStats() will
display the run time of each task as a % of the total run time of all
CPUs (task run time / no of CPUs) / (total run time / 100 )
children.name: FREERTOS_GENERATE_RUN_TIME_STATS
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS to collect run time stats

children.help:
FreeRTOS will enter light sleep mode if no tasks need to run for this number
of ticks.
children.name: FREERTOS_IDLE_TIME_BEFORE_SLEEP
children.title: Minimum number of ticks to enter sleep mode for

children.help:
If power management support is enabled, FreeRTOS will be able to put
the system into light sleep mode when no tasks need to run for a number
of ticks. This number can be set using FREERTOS_IDLE_TIME_BEFORE_SLEEP option.
This feature is also known as "automatic light sleep".

Note that timers created using esp_timer APIs may prevent the system from
entering sleep mode, even when no tasks need to run.
To skip unnecessary wake-up initialize a timer with the "skip_unhandled_events" option as true.

If disabled, automatic light sleep support will be disabled.
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TICKLESS_IDLE
children.title: Tickless idle support

children.help:
If enabled, all FreeRTOS task functions will be enclosed in a wrapper function.
If a task function mistakenly returns (i.e. does not delete), the call flow will
return to the wrapper function. The wrapper function will then log an error and
abort the application. This option is also required for GDB backtraces and C++
exceptions to work correctly inside top-level task functions.
children.name: FREERTOS_TASK_FUNCTION_WRAPPER
children.title: Enclose all task functions in a wrapper function

children.help:
If enabled, assert that when a mutex semaphore is given, the task giving the
semaphore is the task which is currently holding the mutex.
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_MUTEX_GIVEN_BY_OWNER
children.title: Check that mutex semaphore is given by owner task

children.help:
If enabled, context of port*_CRITICAL calls (ISR or Non-ISR)
would be checked to be in compliance with Vanilla FreeRTOS.
e.g Calling port*_CRITICAL from ISR context would cause assert failure
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_PORT_CRITICAL_COMPLIANCE
children.title: Tests compliance with Vanilla FreeRTOS port*_CRITICAL calls

children.help:
When enabled the selected Non-ISR FreeRTOS functions will be placed into Flash memory instead of IRAM.
This saves up to 8KB of IRAM depending on which functions are used.
children.name: FREERTOS_PLACE_FUNCTIONS_INTO_FLASH
children.title: Place FreeRTOS functions into Flash

children.help: Hidden option, gets selected by CONFIG_ESPxx_DEBUG_OCDAWARE
children.name: FREERTOS_DEBUG_OCDAWARE

children.help:
When enabled, the usage of float type is allowed inside Level 1
ISRs.
children.name: FREERTOS_FPU_IN_ISR
children.title: Allow use of float inside Level 1 ISR (EXPERIMENTAL)

children.help:
When enabled, the functions related to snapshots, such as vTaskGetSnapshot or uxTaskGetSnapshotAll,
will be placed in flash. Note that if enabled, these functions cannot be called when cache is disabled.
children.name: FREERTOS_PLACE_SNAPSHOT_FUNS_INTO_FLASH
children.title: Place task snapshot functions into flash

children.help:
When enabled, the functions related to snapshots, such as vTaskGetSnapshot or uxTaskGetSnapshotAll,
are compiled and linked.
children.name: FREERTOS_ENABLE_TASK_SNAPSHOT
children.title: Enable task snapshot functions

children.help:
Set the assert behavior / level for HAL component.
HAL component assert level can be set separately,
but the level can't exceed the system assertion level.
e.g. If the system assertion is disabled, then the HAL
assertion can't be enabled either. If the system assertion
is enable, then the HAL assertion can still be disabled
by this Kconfig option.
children.name: HAL_DEFAULT_ASSERTION_LEVEL
children.title: Default HAL assertion level
Hardware Abstraction Layer (HAL) and Low Level (LL)

children.help:
Specify how much output to see in logs by default.
You can set lower verbosity level at runtime using
esp_log_level_set function.

By default, this setting limits which log statements
are compiled into the program. For example, selecting
"Warning" would mean that changing log level to "Debug"
at runtime will not be possible. To allow increasing log
level above the default at runtime, see the next option.
children.name: LOG_DEFAULT_LEVEL
children.title: Default log verbosity

children.help:
This config option sets the highest log verbosity that it's possible to select
at runtime by calling esp_log_level_set(). This level may be higher than
the default verbosity level which is set when the app starts up.

This can be used enable debugging output only at a critical point, for a particular
tag, or to minimize startup time but then enable more logs once the firmware has
loaded.

Note that increasing the maximum available log level will increase the firmware
binary size.

This option only applies to logging from the app, the bootloader log level is
fixed at compile time to the separate "Bootloader log verbosity" setting.
children.name: LOG_MAXIMUM_LEVEL
children.title: Maximum log verbosity

children.help:
Enable ANSI terminal color codes in bootloader output.

In order to view these, your terminal program must support ANSI color codes.
children.name: LOG_COLORS
children.title: Use ANSI terminal colors in log output

children.help:
Choose what sort of timestamp is displayed in the log output:

- Milliseconds since boot is calulated from the RTOS tick count multiplied
  by the tick period. This time will reset after a software reboot.
  e.g. (90000)

- System time is taken from POSIX time functions which use the ESP32's
  RTC and FRC1 timers to maintain an accurate time. The system time is
  initialized to 0 on startup, it can be set with an SNTP sync, or with
  POSIX time functions. This time will not reset after a software reboot.
  e.g. (00:01:30.000)

- NOTE: Currently this will not get used in logging from binary blobs
  (i.e WiFi & Bluetooth libraries), these will always print
  milliseconds since boot.
children.name: LOG_TIMESTAMP_SOURCE
children.title: Log Timestamps

children.help:
This option allows configuring the desired line endings sent to UART
when a newline ('\n', LF) appears on stdout.
Three options are possible:

CRLF: whenever LF is encountered, prepend it with CR

LF: no modification is applied, stdout is sent as is

CR: each occurence of LF is replaced with CR

This option doesn't affect behavior of the UART driver (drivers/uart.h).
children.name: NEWLIB_STDOUT_LINE_ENDING
children.title: Line ending for UART output

children.help:
This option allows configuring which input sequence on UART produces
a newline ('\n', LF) on stdin.
Three options are possible:

CRLF: CRLF is converted to LF

LF: no modification is applied, input is sent to stdin as is

CR: each occurence of CR is replaced with LF

This option doesn't affect behavior of the UART driver (drivers/uart.h).
children.name: NEWLIB_STDIN_LINE_ENDING
children.title: Line ending for UART input

children.help:
ESP32 ROM contains parts of newlib C library, including printf/scanf family
of functions. These functions have been compiled with so-called "nano"
formatting option. This option doesn't support 64-bit integer formats and C99
features, such as positional arguments.

For more details about "nano" formatting option, please see newlib readme file,
search for '--enable-newlib-nano-formatted-io':
https://sourceware.org/newlib/README

If this option is enabled, build system will use functions available in
ROM, reducing the application binary size. Functions available in ROM run
faster than functions which run from flash. Functions available in ROM can
also run when flash instruction cache is disabled.

If you need 64-bit integer formatting support or C99 features, keep this
option disabled.
children.name: NEWLIB_NANO_FORMAT
children.title: Enable 'nano' formatting options for printf/scanf family

children.help:
If this option is enabled, if SPI flash write verification fails then a log error line
will be written with the address, expected & actual values. This can be useful when
debugging hardware SPI flash problems.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_LOG_FAILED_WRITE
children.title: Log errors if verification fails

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any SPI flash write which tries to set zero bits in the flash to
ones will log a warning. Such writes will not result in the requested data appearing identically
in flash once written, as SPI NOR flash can only set bits to one when an entire sector is erased.
After erasing, individual bits can only be written from one to zero.

Note that some software (such as SPIFFS) which is aware of SPI NOR flash may write one bits as an
optimisation, relying on the data in flash becoming a bitwise AND of the new data and any existing data.
Such software will log spurious warnings if this option is enabled.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_WARN_SETTING_ZERO_TO_ONE
children.title: Log warning if writing zero bits to ones

children.help:
If this option is enabled, any time SPI flash is written then the data will be read
back and verified. This can catch hardware problems with SPI flash, or flash which
was not erased before verification.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_VERIFY_WRITE
children.title: Verify SPI flash writes

children.help:
This option enables the following APIs:

- spi_flash_reset_counters
- spi_flash_dump_counters
- spi_flash_get_counters

These APIs may be used to collect performance data for spi_flash APIs
and to help understand behaviour of libraries which use SPI flash.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ENABLE_COUNTERS
children.title: Enable operation counters

children.help:
Enable this flag to use patched versions of SPI flash ROM driver functions.
This option should be enabled, if any one of the following is true: (1) need to write
to flash on ESP32-D2WD; (2) main SPI flash is connected to non-default pins; (3) main
SPI flash chip is manufactured by ISSI.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ROM_DRIVER_PATCH
children.title: Enable SPI flash ROM driver patched functions

children.help:
Enable this flag to use new SPI flash driver functions from ROM instead of ESP-IDF.

If keeping this as "n" in your project, you will have less free IRAM.
But you can use all of our flash features.

If making this as "y" in your project, you will increase free IRAM.
But you may miss out on some flash features and support for new flash chips.

Currently the ROM cannot support the following features:

- SPI_FLASH_AUTO_SUSPEND (C3, S3)
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ROM_IMPL
children.title: Use esp_flash implementation in ROM

children.help:
SPI flash APIs can optionally abort or return a failure code
if erasing or writing addresses that fall at the beginning
of flash (covering the bootloader and partition table) or that
overlap the app partition that contains the running app.

It is not recommended to ever write to these regions from an IDF app,
and this check prevents logic errors or corrupted firmware memory from
damaging these regions.

Note that this feature *does not* check calls to the esp_rom_xxx SPI flash
ROM functions. These functions should not be called directly from IDF
applications.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_DANGEROUS_WRITE
children.title: Writing to dangerous flash regions

children.help:
The implementation of SPI flash has been greatly changed in IDF v4.0.
Enable this option to use the legacy implementation.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_USE_LEGACY_IMPL
children.title: Use the legacy implementation before IDF v4.0

children.help:
Each SPI bus needs a lock for arbitration among devices. This allows multiple
devices on a same bus, but may reduce the speed of esp_flash driver access to the
main flash chip.

If you only need to use esp_flash driver to access the main flash chip, disable
this option, and the lock will be bypassed on SPI1 bus. Otherwise if extra devices
are needed to attach to SPI1 bus, enable this option.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SHARE_SPI1_BUS
children.title: Support other devices attached to SPI1 bus

children.help:
Some flash chips can have very high "max" erase times, especially for block erase (32KB or 64KB).
This option allows to bypass "block erase" and always do sector erase commands.
This will be much slower overall in most cases, but improves latency for other code to run.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_BYPASS_BLOCK_ERASE
children.title: Bypass a block erase and always do sector erase

children.help:
If a duration of one erase command is large
then it will yield CPUs after finishing a current command.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_DURATION_MS
children.title: Duration of erasing to yield CPUs (ms)

children.help: Defines how many ticks will be before returning to continue a erasing.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ERASE_YIELD_TICKS
children.title: CPU release time (tick) for an erase operation

children.help:
This allows to yield the CPUs between erase commands.
Prevents starvation of other tasks.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_YIELD_DURING_ERASE
children.title: Enables yield operation during flash erase

children.help:
This option is default n before ESP32-C3, because it needs bootloader support.

CAUTION: If you want to OTA to an app with this feature turned on, please make
sure the bootloader has the support for it. (later than IDF v4.3)

Auto-suspend feature only supported by XMC chip.
If you are using an official module, please contact Espressif Business support.
Also reading auto suspend part in `SPI Flash API` document before you enable this function.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_AUTO_SUSPEND
children.title: Auto suspend long erase/write operations (READ DOCS FIRST)

children.help:
Flash write is broken down in terms of multiple (smaller) write operations.
This configuration options helps to set individual write chunk size, smaller
value here ensures that cache (and non-IRAM resident interrupts) remains
disabled for shorter duration.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_WRITE_CHUNK_SIZE
children.title: Flash write chunk size

children.help:
SPI Flash driver uses the flash size configured in bootloader header by default.
Enable this option to override flash size with latest ESPTOOLPY_FLASHSIZE value from
the app header if the size in the bootloader header is incorrect.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SIZE_OVERRIDE
children.title: Override flash size in bootloader header by ESPTOOLPY_FLASHSIZE

children.help: This option is helpful if you are using a flash chip whose timeout is quite large or unpredictable.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_CHECK_ERASE_TIMEOUT_DISABLED
children.title: Flash timeout checkout disabled

children.help:
This option allows the chip driver list to be customized, instead of using the default list provided by
ESP-IDF.

When this option is enabled, the default list is no longer compiled or linked. Instead, the
`default_registered_chips` structure must be provided by the user.

See example: custom_chip_driver under examples/storage for more details.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_OVERRIDE_CHIP_DRIVER_LIST
children.title: Override default chip driver list

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of ISSI chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_ISSI_CHIP
children.title: ISSI

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of MXIC chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_MXIC_CHIP
children.title: MXIC

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of GD (GigaDevice) chips if chip vendor not
directly given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. If you are using Wrover
modules, please don't disable this, otherwise your flash may not work in 4-bit
mode.

This adds support for variant chips, however will extend detecting time and image
size. Note that the default chip driver supports the GD chips with product ID
60H.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_GD_CHIP
children.title: GigaDevice

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of Winbond chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_WINBOND_CHIP
children.title: Winbond

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of BOYA chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_BOYA_CHIP
children.title: BOYA

children.help:
Enable this to support auto detection of Octal MXIC chips if chip vendor not directly
given by ``chip_drv`` member of the chip struct. This adds support for variant
chips, however will extend detecting time.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_SUPPORT_MXIC_OPI_CHIP
children.title: mxic (opi)

children.help:
This option enables flash read/write operations to encrypted partition/s. This option
is kept enabled irrespective of state of flash encryption feature. However, in case
application is not using flash encryption feature and is in need of some additional
memory from IRAM region (~1KB) then this config can be disabled.
children.name: SPI_FLASH_ENABLE_ENCRYPTED_READ_WRITE
children.title: Enable encrypted partition read/write operations

children.help:
Soc, esp32, and driver components, the most common
components. Some header of these components are included
implicitly by headers of other components before IDF v4.0.
It's not required for high-level components, but still
included through long header chain everywhere.

This is harmful to the modularity. So it's changed in IDF
v4.0.

You can still include these headers in a legacy way until it
is totally deprecated by enable this option.
children.name: LEGACY_INCLUDE_COMMON_HEADERS
children.title: Include headers across components as before IDF v4.0
